Future video game technologies that were spot on

25/06/2022

Adam Frost explores a few times video games featured future technologies

Image by Avia Husk

By Katy Leverett

Most people have watched the beloved Back to the Future films and played the accompanying video games. Released in 1989 with a game of the same name in 1990, Back to the Future Two predicted some wacky technologies they thought would come to pass by 2015. While some of their predictions were a hit and a miss â€“ such as Martyâ€™s hover-board or being able to time travel â€“ here are a few times we should have paid closer attention to videogame inventions such as Back to the Future, BioShock and many more. One of the most outlandish, but undoubtedly popular predictions amongst not just this franchise but many videogames and films was the use of biometric locks.
While Back to the Future was a couple years late with its prediction (biometrics being available on the iPhone 3 in 2013) the depictions of the technology were pretty much spot on. Consumers can now open their phones, bank accounts and even garage door locks with the touch of a thumb or finger. For everyoneâ€™s sake letâ€™s hope that fingerprint theft through cutting peoples fingers off does not become a widespread issue.
The Back to the Future series and many other games through the years predicted the use of the human body as a replacement to the traditional controller. In 2010, perhaps building upon the motion capture technology used in the Wii remotes, Microsoft released the Xbox Kinect system which allowed players to play without the need for a traditional controller. Instead, they were the controller and, while the technology might not be as flawless or popular as many video games have predicted it would be, it nevertheless exists and proves that these ideas were not perhaps as outlandish as viewers of films in the 1990â€™s though they were. There are also currently a whole host of wearable technologies that act as smart clothes. In 2019 Nike released a version of self-lacing shoes similar to the ones Marty. But the range of smart clothes available does not stop there. Athletic monitors for heartrate, breathing and even calories burnt to one-size fits all clothing with adjustable fabrics are all available.

Anyone familiar with first person shooters will know, and perhaps complain about auto-aim ruining the competitive experience of players. Although for anyone with a spare $17,000, the XS1 tracking rifle provides hunters with a gun that can automatically fire when two targets are aligned, and the wind and bullet trajectory are calculated to be optimal for a clean hit. While this may seem like a very dangerous technology, the health concerns that could be argued for this being military exclusive technology, hunters are already using these weapons and one of the biggest barriers to getting your hands on one is the backlog of orders Linux has received. What makes this technology feel even more like playing a video game is the fact that hunters can even use the tech to record and publish their kills online. Almost as if they are using a kill cam from Call of Duty.

The final technology on this list that makes it feel like we are living in a video game is Modafinil. If you have ever played a Bioshock game, a round of Call of Duty zombies or even a Mario game you will be familiar with the concept of a powerup. Supposedly, Modafinil allows consumers to stay awake for upwards of 40 hours while not losing any mental capacity or suffering any physical harm. While the use of this sort of drug might be a bit excessive for university exams, the workplace and military applications seem to be endless as we move ever closer to perfecting the flawless worker or super soldier.

What do you think? Were video games just ahead of their time in predicting these technologies, were they already in development or is the advancement of technologies that feel ridiculously futuristic just inevitable?
